title: Douglas County Past : Store owner thwarts bandits with unloaded shotgun ; historic engine featured at fair
body_text:
Aug. 16, 1924
Battling Dan Lund thwarts auto bandits
ADVERTISEMENT
“Battling” Dan Lund, proprietor of the Manitou Falls confectionery store, lived up to his title early Friday morning when he chased from his premises with an unloaded shotgun two would-be bandits, believed to be Ray Lofgren and “Billy Murphy,” who, a few hours later succeeded in robbing the Ed Pringbein Mercantile store at the St. Croix river on highway No. 35, not, however, before young Lofgren was seriously wounded.
Springbein, who came in this morning from his store to make a report to police, stated that he stopped at the Manitou Falls place where he was informed that, shortly after 12 o’clock Friday morning, prior to the time when he himself fired at Lofgren, someone had attempted to get into the Lund store.
As a Minnesota congressman, Chisholm native John Blatnik was instrumental in getting the bridge between Duluth and Superior built. As a captain and paratrooper with the U.S. Army Air Force. Blatnik spent eight months working behind enemy lines in Yugoslavia. The work included setting up an escape system for downed American airmen. One of them was a Duluth man: Swante Norlund.
For this episode, Telegram reporter Maria Lockwood is joined by Briana Fiandt, curator of collections and exhibits for the Richard I. Bong Veterans Historical Center in Superior, as they discuss the life of Blatnik.
You can find photos for this episode at superiortelegram.com. You can also find additional episodes here.

Lund, hearing them, seized an unloaded shotgun and faced the two would-be robbers. They scampered away from the store and made off in a high powered machine.
Superior news in brief
Fire scare – Residents of Lake Nebagamon were given another “fire scare” last night when a bright blaze was seen in the sky on county trunk B between Hawthorne and Lake Nebagamon. Many who rushed to the spot claimed it was a fiery cross but the exact location of the fire was not determined. One young lady was precipitated into the water of the lake in her haste to cross the lake to view the fire. She swam to shore.
Girls’ Y camp closing today
The fifth annual YMCA Girls’ camp at Lake Nebagamon is closing today and its 30 or more girls with their director and leaders are returning to their homes after a “never-to-be-forgotten two weeks” spent in work, play and study.
ADVERTISEMENT
About 75 guests, most of them from Superior, arrived before, during and after dinner and the play, written by the girls with the help of Miss Agnes Currie, director and coach, was staged.
Miss Madge Helmer as the “Spirit of America” appeared first, looking for boys and girls of the right character and training to carry on her work. Marie Yeakey, “Spirit of the ‘Y’” offered to help, and while the two watched the aides of the latter appeared.
“Athletics,” Constance Bubar and Alice Dunham; “Nature Study,” Martha Stewart; “Spiritual Growth,” Verna Richardson.
Firm started 20 years ago
The Christenson creamery of Superior, 423 Hughitt avenue, manufacturer of “Cloverdale butter,” is among the oldest and best established concerns in Superior. It had its origin about 20 years ago, when Helge S. Haugsrud began operating a general produce and creamery company.
Gradually he shifted from the produce field until he was finally specializing in creamery work and particularly in eggs and “Cloverland butter.”
Aug. 16, 1974
ADVERTISEMENT
$10,000 offer for sand pit rejected
Douglas County’s offer of $10,000 for the purchase of a 40-acre sand pit in the Town of Superior was rejected Thursday by the owner of the land.
The sand pit is adjacent to another pit owned by Douglas County and is estimated to contain about 500,000 cubic feet of sand.
Herbert Theien, a Superior realtor representing William Kimmes, the owner of the property, said he has talked his client into accepting $11,000 for the land.
The land and highway committees of the Douglas County Board of Supervisors set the $10,000 offer on a split vote during a joint session in the courthouse Thursday morning.
UWS eleven to launch practices
As Head Coach Ed Bender enters his third year of reconstructing the football program at University of Wisconsin-Superior, the Yellowjackets began to wear the mantle of maturity as they look forward to the 1974 season.
ADVERTISEMENT
Bender expects 74 candidates, including 35 lettermen, to show up Monday with full scale drills to start twice daily on Tuesday.
Most of the starting offensive and defensive units are back together.
On offense, this includes the backfield quartet of quarterback Frank Lee, 6-0, 195, junior, Sterling, Ill.; halfbacks Gary Beckman, 5-11, 179, senior, Embarrass, Minn., and Mike Raskovich, 58, 164, senior, Nashwauk, Minn., and fullback Steve Shilling, 5-11, 205, sophomore, Duluth.
Leading the pass-receiving corps are Jerry Uchytil, 5-9, 160, senior split end from Superior, who is one of the leading aerial grabbers in the WSUC, and tight end Jim Peck, 6-3, 210, senior, who started last year.
The starting guards are back and include Mike Polkowski, 6-0, 223, junior, Iron River, and Del Gander, 5-11, 225, junior, Solon Springs.
Aug. 17, 1974
8 shooters hit perfect straights
ADVERTISEMENT
Four perfect straights were fired in each of two rounds in the Superior Trap League.
In the first round, Ted White, Jim Nordberg, Bill Nicoski and Henry Pearson hit 25x25 straights while Jim Beebe, Cliff Van Guilder, Bruce Neilsen and Lee Wesolowski had perfect straights in round No. 2.
In round No. 2 those at 24x25 were Henry Pearson, Bill Nicoski, Jerry Larson, John Zakowski Jr., Jim Cosgrove, Fred Doolittle and Jim Thompson. Georgia Flood had a 23x25 to lead women shooters and Anna Mae Zakowski was second.
Smekafske, Smith powder puff race winners
A crowd of over 1,400 racing fans were on hand to witness the annual Powder Puff Derby at the stock car races Friday night at the Tri-State Speedway.
The two leaders in the street stock powder puff race tangled on their airport turn and ended up sitting out the last lap on the turn. Debbie VanPuymbrouck and Ann Casey came around the turn side by side and then they tangled to end the night’s race for them. Jackie Smekafske and Bonnie Gillette went on to take their places. Gail Smith successfully defended her super stock title by passing Jan Miles with one lap to go. Goal was driving the familiar number 64 belonging to Bob Smith.
Aug. 19, 1924
ADVERTISEMENT
First G.N. engine to steam up avenue
The William Crooks, first locomotive in Minnesota, which traversed the prairies of the Gopher state when Abraham Lincoln was president, will be one of the main attractions of the Tri-State fair this year.
Through the courtesy of the Great Northern railway, the old locomotive, which was the first engine of the now extensive Great Northern system, will steam up Tower avenue on Sunday preceding the fair opening to the fairgrounds, where it will be on display through the three days of the fair.
It will be transferred from the Great Northern tracks at a place to be determined by the company engineers, and will proceed up Tower avenue under its own steam on the tracks of the Duluth Street Railway company.
